Cell.Data: Detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses

Use to record detailed information about conditions, problems or diagnoses recognized by a clinician. There are many uses including: recording a Diagnosis during an Encounter; populating a problem List or a Summary Statement, such as a Discharge Summary

* Age is questionable, you might well need a range of Age or even (in practice)
a text like "in their teens". => new ballot comment.
* Todo: discuss the applicability of assessing stages
* Change the description: it is circular

This records identifiers associated with this condition that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation)
Need to allow connection to a wider workflow
Indicates the patient who the condition record is associated with
Encounter during which the condition was first asserted
Person who takes responsibility for asserting the existence of the condition as part of the electronic record
Estimated or actual date the condition/problem/diagnosis was first detected/suspected
Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis
Identification of the condition, problem or diagnosis.
A category assigned to the condition. E.g. complaint | symptom | finding | diagnosis
The categorization is often highly contextual and may appear poorly differentiated or not very useful in other contexts
'problem' if from PRB-3. 'diagnosis' if from DG1 segment in PV1 message
The clinical status of the condition

.code (pre or post-coordinated in)
Can use valueNegationInd for refuted
The degree of confidence that this condition is correct
A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
Coding of the severity with a terminology is preferred, where possible
Can be pre/post-coordinated into value. Or ./inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="severity"].value
Estimated or actual date, or age
Estimated or actual date the condition began, in the opinion of the clinician
Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition began to occur

The date or estimated date that the condition resolved or went into remission. This is called "abatement" because of the many overloaded connotations associated with "remission" or "resolution" - Conditions are never really resolved, but they can abate.

There is no explicit distinction between resolution and remission because in many cases the distinction is not clear. Age is generally used when the patient reports an age at which the Condition abated.
If there is no abatement element, it is unknown whether the condition has resolved or entered remission; applications and users should generally assume that the condition is still valid

.effectiveTime.high or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ].source[classCode=OBS, moodCode=EVN, code="age at remission"].value or .inboundRelationship[typeCode=SUBJ]source[classCode=CONC, moodCode=EVN].status=completed
Clinical stage or grade of a condition. May include formal severity assessments
A simple summary of the stage such as "Stage 3". The determination of the stage is disease-specific
Reference to a formal record of the evidence on which the staging assessment is based
When an assessment resource / framework is developed, this will be changed from Any to something narrower
Supporting Evidence / manifestations that are the basis on which this condition is suspected or confirmed
The evidence may be a simple list of coded symptoms/manifestations, or references to observations or formal assessments, or both
A manifestation or symptom that led to the recording of this condition
Links to other relevant information, including pathology reports
The anatomical location where this condition manifests itself
May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both
Code that identifies the structural location
Causes or precedents for this Condition
Further conditions, problems, diagnoses, procedures or events that are related in some way to this condition, or the substance that caused/triggered this Condition
Although a condition may be caused by a substance, this is not intended to be used to record allergies/adverse reactions to substances
could infer from presence of multiple PRB segments in a PPR message that the problems are related, but not clear how to communicate the nature of the relationship
The type of relationship that this condition has to the related item
Relationship target by means of a predefined code
Code that identifies the target of this relationship. The code takes the place of a detailed instance target
Additional information about the Condition. This is a general notes/comments entry for description of the Condition, its diagnosis and prognosis
Stage SHALL have summary or assessment
evidence SHALL have code or details
location SHALL have code or details
Relationship SHALL have either a code or a target
When the Condition started (if started on a date)
Identification of the Condition or diagnosis.
A category assigned to the condition. E.g. finding | Condition | diagnosis | concern | condition
The clinical status of the Condition or diagnosis
The degree of confidence that this condition is correct
A subjective assessment of the severity of the condition as evaluated by the clinician.
The type of relationship between a condition and its related item
this condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance and is a consequence of it
The consequence may be good or bad
this condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance, but it is not known whether they are causually linked
This condition follows the identified condition/procedure/substance, but may or may not be a consequence (i.e. causually linked)
This is a tentative diagnosis - still a candidate that is under consideration
The patient is being treated on the basis that this is the condition, but it is still not confirmed
There is sufficient diagnostic and/or clinical evidence to treat this as a confirmed condition
This condition has been ruled out by diagnostic and clinical evidence
